Baby WASH Programming. UNICEF Eastern and Southern Africa: UNICEF; 2020.  

Extract;
People become infected with intestinal parasitic worms (also known as helminths) by eating contaminated food or through contact with contaminated soil. 

Diseases such as typhoid fever – a bacterial infection – are also caused by ingesting contaminated food or water.
rows.reference_link_title_2: 5 Keys to Safer Food Manual.  WHO; 2006.
rows.title: The five ways to keeping your food safe

title.eng: The five ways to keeping your food safe

text.eng:
People become infected with intestinal worms by eating unsafe food.

Diseases such as typhoid fever (bacteria infection) can also happen by eating unsafe food or water.

There are five ways to keeping your food safe:
* Keep clean.
* Separate raw and cooked food.
* Cook food thoroughly.
* Keep food at a safe temperature.
* Use safe water.

rows.text:
People become infected with intestinal worms by eating unsafe food.

Diseases such as typhoid fever (bacteria infection) can also happen by eating unsafe food or water.

There are five ways to keeping your food safe:
* Keep clean.
* Separate raw and cooked food.
* Cook food thoroughly.
* Keep food at a safe temperature.
* Use safe water.

rows.reference:
5 Keys to Safer Food Manual.  Geneva: WHO; 2016.

Extract
Keep Clean
i. Wash your hands before handling food and often during food preparation
ii. Wash your hands after going to the toilet
iii. Wash and sanitize all surfaces and equipment used for food preparation
iv. Protect kitchen areas and food from insects, pests, and other animals
rows.reference_link_title: 5 Keys to Safer Food Manual.  WHO; 2006.
rows.title: Keep clean

text.eng:
* Wash your hands with soap before touching food and while cooking.
* Wash your hands after going to the toilet.
* Clean your cooking space and tools.
* Keep bugs, pests, and other animals away from the cooking area.
* Cover food if you can.

text_2.eng: Small pathogens that cause disease can transfer from your unwashed hands, chopping boards, cloths, and utensils.  Keep these clean.

rows.text:
* Wash your hands with soap before touching food and while cooking.
* Wash your hands after going to the toilet.
* Clean your cooking space and tools.
* Keep bugs, pests, and other animals away from the cooking area.
* Cover food if you can.
rows.reference 3:
5 Keys to Safer Food Manual.  Geneva: WHO; 2016.

Extract:
While most microorganisms do not cause
disease, dangerous microorganisms are
widely found in soil, water, animals
and people. These microorganisms are
carried on hands, wiping cloths and
utensils, especially cutting boards and
the slightest contact can transfer them
to food and cause foodborne diseases.
rows.reference_link_title_3: 5 Keys to Safer Food Manual.  WHO; 2006.
rows.subtitle: Why?
rows.text_2: Small pathogens that cause disease can transfer from your unwashed hands, chopping boards, cloths, and utensils.  Keep these clean.

rows.reference:
5 Keys to Safer Food Manual.  Geneva: WHO; 2016.

Extract
Separate raw and cooked
i.  Separate raw meat, poultry, and seafood from other foods
ii.  Use separate equipment and utensils, such as  knives and cutting boards, for handling raw foods
iii.  Store food in containers to avoid contact between raw and prepared foods
rows.reference_link_title: 5 Keys to Safer Food Manual.  WHO; 2006.
rows.title: Separate raw and cooked

text.eng:
* Wash your knife and chopping board after cutting raw meat, chicken, or fish, before you use them for cutting other foods.
* Store food in covered containers when you can. This will keep it safe from pests, moisture, rot, and also stop the mixing of raw and prepared foods.
* Clean up any leftover ingredients when done, especially raw meat.

text_2.eng: Germs causing illness can be found in raw food (such as meat, chicken, and seafood). These can be transferred to other foods during food preparation or storage.  Separating raw and cooked food is therefore important.

rows.text:
* Wash your knife and chopping board after cutting raw meat, chicken, or fish, before you use them for cutting other foods.
* Store food in covered containers when you can. This will keep it safe from pests, moisture, rot, and also stop the mixing of raw and prepared foods.
* Clean up any leftover ingredients when done, especially raw meat.
rows.reference 3:
5 Keys to Safer Food Manual.  Geneva: WHO; 2016.

Extract:
Raw food, especially meat, poultry and
seafood, and their juices, can contain
dangerous microorganisms which may
be transferred onto other foods during
food preparation and storage.
rows.reference_link_title_3: 5 Keys to Safer Food Manual.  WHO; 2006.
rows.subtitle: Why?
rows.text_2: Germs causing illness can be found in raw food (such as meat, chicken, and seafood). These can be transferred to other foods during food preparation or storage.  Separating raw and cooked food is therefore important.

rows.reference:
5 Keys to Safer Food Manual.  Geneva: WHO; 2016.

Extract
i. Cook food thoroughly, especially meat, poultry, eggs, and seafood
ii. Bring food like soups and stews to boil to make sure they have reached 70 degrees Celsius. For meat and poultry, make sure that juices are clear, not pink. Ideally, use a thermometer.
iii. Reheat cooked food thoroughly
rows.reference_link_title: 5 Keys to Safer Food Manual.  WHO; 2006.
rows.title: Cook thoroughly

text.eng:
* Cook food thoroughly, especially meat, chicken, eggs, and seafood. 
* When making stews, remember to bring them to a boil.
* Reheat cooked food thoroughly.
* Boil the water you use to make baby foods and drinks.

text_2.eng: Cooking with very high heat kills almost all dangerous germs causing illness.  Let's make sure that cooked food is heated thoroughly.

rows.text:
* Cook food thoroughly, especially meat, chicken, eggs, and seafood. 
* When making stews, remember to bring them to a boil.
* Reheat cooked food thoroughly.
* Boil the water you use to make baby foods and drinks.
rows.reference 3:
5 Keys to Safer Food Manual.  Geneva: WHO; 2016.

Extract:
Proper cooking kills almost all dangerous
microorganisms. Studies have shown that
cooking food to a temperature of 70°C can
help ensure it is safe for consumption.
Foods that require special attention
include minced meats, rolled roasts, large
joints of meat and whole poultry.
rows.subtitle: Why?
rows.text_2: Cooking with very high heat kills almost all dangerous germs causing illness.  Let's make sure that cooked food is heated thoroughly.

rows.reference:
5 Keys to Safer Food Manual.  Geneva: WHO; 2016.

Extract
Keep food at a safe temperature
i. Do not leave cooked food at room temperature for more than 2 hours
ii. Refrigerate promptly all cooked food and food that can go bad
(preferably below 5 degrees Celsius)
iii.  Keep cooked food piping hot (more than 60°C) prior to serving
iv. Do not store food too long even in the refrigerator
v. Do not thaw frozen food at room temperature
rows.reference_link_title: 5 Keys to Safer Food Manual.  WHO; 2006.
rows.title: Keep food at a safe temperature

title.eng: Keep food at a safe temperature

text.eng:
* Leaving cooked food out for longer than two hours can be unsafe.
* Keep cooked food really hot before eating.

text_2.eng: When food is stored at room temperature germs can grow.  That's why it's important to heat food well and eat it soon after cooking.

rows.text:
* Leaving cooked food out for longer than two hours can be unsafe.
* Keep cooked food really hot before eating.
rows.reference 3:
5 Keys to Safer Food Manual.  Geneva: WHO; 2016.

Extract:
Microorganisms can multiply very
quickly if food is stored at room
temperature. By holding at temperatures below 5°C or above 60°C, the
growth of microorganisms is slowed
down or stopped. Some dangerous
microorganisms still grow below 5°C.
rows.subtitle: Why?
rows.text_2: When food is stored at room temperature germs can grow.  That's why it's important to heat food well and eat it soon after cooking.

rows.reference:
5 Keys to Safer Food Manual.  Geneva: WHO; 2016.

Extract
i. Use safe water or treat it to make it safe
ii. Select fresh and wholesome foods 
iii. Choose foods processed for safety, such as pasteurized milk
iv. Wash fruits and vegetables, especially if eaten raw
v. Do not use food beyond its expiry date
rows.reference_link_title: 5 Keys to Safer Food Manual.  WHO; 2006.
rows.title: Use safe water

text.eng:
* Use safe water (see our modules on safe drinking water for more tips). Even though your water might look clean, it's still important to treat or boil it.
* Remember to wash your fruits and vegetables with safe water.

text_2.eng: Your vegetables, fruits, meats, and even water can hold dangerous germs that cause illness. Washing with safe water and peeling raw foods decreases your risk of getting sick.

rows.text:
* Use safe water (see our modules on safe drinking water for more tips). Even though your water might look clean, it's still important to treat or boil it.
* Remember to wash your fruits and vegetables with safe water.
rows.reference 3:
5 Keys to Safer Food Manual.  Geneva: WHO; 2016.

Extract:
Raw materials, including water and ice,
maybe contaminated with dangerous
microorganisms and chemicals. Toxic
chemicals may be formed in damaged
and mouldy foods. Care in selection of
raw materials and simple measures
such as washing and peeling may
reduce the risk.
rows.subtitle: Why?
rows.text_2: Your vegetables, fruits, meats, and even water can hold dangerous germs that cause illness. Washing with safe water and peeling raw foods decreases your risk of getting sick.
